newsitem.title: USA: VEBA AG unit to buy Wyle for $810 million.
newsitem.headline: VEBA AG unit to buy Wyle for $810 million.

text.p: Electronics distributor Wyle Electronics has agreed to be acquired by a subsidiary of the German utilities giant VEBA AG in a deal worth $810 million, the companies said on Thursday.
Under the agreement, approved by the boards of both companies, VEBA's Raab Karcher AG unit will pay $50 cash for each Wyle share.
Wyle shares closed at $42.81 on the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday.
EBV Electronics Inc, a subsidiary of Raab Karcher, will begin a tender offer for all outstanding Wyle common shares, at $50 each, on or before July 10, the companies said.
The takeover will not result in any layoffs at Wyle, they said.
The $810 million price tag includes Raab's assumption of Wyle debt, the companies said.

Raab Karcher is a European-based distribution and services group with worldwide activities. In 1996 it generated revenues of $7.0 billion and had 29,000 employees. Its corporate parent VEBA is one of the largest industrial groups in Europe.
Wyle is a leading U.S. distributor of electronic components and computer systems. Its 1996 sales totalled $1.2 billion.
